text: The night is cold.
Something moved.
It watches.
Run now.
Don't look.
Help me.
I'm scared.
Not here.
The door was open.
I heard breathing.
The floor creaks.
Someone is here.
The lights died.
Get out now.
Lock the door.
Hide and wait.
The lights flickered once.
Footsteps behind me now.
The window shattered.
I smell something burning.
The clock stopped at three.
It's getting closer.
My hands are shaking.
I can't breathe.
The mirror showed someone else.
My shadow moved without me.
The walls are breathing.
I can hear it thinking.
The painting's eyes followed me.
Fingers scratched the glass.
Something's in the walls.
The air tastes like copper.
Shadows move when you blink.
The whispers know your name.
It stands in the corner now.
The scratching comes from inside.
My reflection didn't blink.
The water turned red.
Eyes in the dark.
It knows what I want.
I locked the door, but it opened anyway.
The phone rang, but no one was there.
The radio plays a song I wrote.
My dog growls at the empty chair.
The smell of rot grows stronger.
The basement door unbolted itself.
My keys are in my hand.
But I never picked them up.
Something scratched the window from inside.
The reflection smiled before I did.
There are wet footprints on the ceiling.
I found teeth marks on my pillow.
The voice from the drain knows me.
There's a handprint on the inside of my window.
I don't own a cat.
Yet there's fur on my bed.
I woke up, but my body was still sleeping.
The stairs creak when no one walks on them.
My handwriting fills pages I never wrote.
The photos show rooms I've never been in.
Something breathes when I hold my breath.
My voice came from the other room.
I'm still in bed, frozen.
It's standing over me.
There are too many shadows in this room.
The voice in the walls knows my secrets.
I hear my own voice calling from outside.
The mirror shows a room that isn't mine.
My childhood photos have a stranger in them.
Someone is wearing my face.
It's getting better at it.
My mother didn't notice.
I counted the people in the photo. There's one extra.
The knocking comes from inside the closet now.
I recognize the corpse. It's wearing my clothes.
The calendar shows tomorrow, but it never comes.
My neighbor waves at me. He died last week.
The scratch marks spell out words.
They spell out my address.
How did it know where I live.
Every night at 3am, I hear my name whispered backwards.
The children's laughter stopped when I turned around.
I keep waking up in places I've never been before.
The TV shows my living room, but I'm not in it.
Something strokes my hair when I pretend to sleep.
Wet handprints appear on my bathroom mirror.
The glass is cold.
Dripping onto the floor.
I found my diary, but the last entry wasn't written by me.
The old woman waves at me every morning. She died last year.
My voicemail has messages from numbers that don't exist.
The bruises on my arms match handprints that aren't mine.
I hear my mother singing, but she's been gone for years.
The mailbox has letters to me from the future.
They all say the same thing.
Don't trust the reflection.
The corridor echoed with footsteps that were not mine.
I saw myself walk past the window, but I'm still inside.
The thing in the attic learned how to say my name perfectly.
I woke up with dirt under my fingernails and grass in my hair.
The news showed my funeral, but I'm still watching it.
My mother is crying in the audience.
But I'm sitting in her row too.
Which one is real.
Something breathes under my bed, and I live alone on the floor.
The doll's eyes follow me, and yesterday it was in a different room.
I stopped counting the days because the calendar keeps resetting.
My therapist doesn't exist, but I've been seeing her for years.
The thing pretending to be my cat almost got the purr right.
I found medicine bottles in my trash.
I never bought them.
But they have my name on them.
I don't remember having a basement, but I can hear digging down there.
My grandmother called today. We buried her three months ago.
The missing posters have my face on them, dated three years from now.
I found a room in my house that wasn't there yesterday. It has my things.
The thing wearing my father's skin keeps forgetting which hand he writes with.
I'm trapped in my own journal.
Reading the future of my death.
Over and over again.
I hear myself screaming from the basement, but I'm too afraid to go down.
The family photos keep changing. Now there's someone standing behind us.
My search history shows websites I've never visited about things I've never done.
The thing in the corner stopped pretending to be a shadow when I noticed it.
I asked the voice in the walls what it wants. It said it's already taken it.
The answer came to me in a dream.
But I remember actually living it.
Which one was the dream.
The thing pretending to be my mother almost got the voice right this time.
I keep finding notes in my handwriting, warning me not to fall asleep.
The children outside are playing a game with rules I've never heard of. They know my name.
I watched myself leave for work this morning from my bedroom window. I never left the house.
My reflection moves half a second after I do. The gap is getting longer.
I found a second bedroom in my apartment.
My doppelg√§nger sleeps in my bed.
It watches me while I sleep.
The GPS keeps directing me to places that don't exist anymore. But something is always waiting there.
I found a door in my house that opens to a hallway I don't recognize. I can hear crying at the end.
My phone autocorrects everything I type to the same phrase: It's already inside. Don't turn around.
The thing that crawls on my ceiling at night learned my wife's voice. Now it whispers that it loves me.
I keep a journal of everyone I meet. According to my entries, I've met myself fourteen times this month.
The ink in my pen is getting darker.
It's starting to look like blood.
It feels warm.
Don't look behind you, I whispered, I'm closer than you think, and I've been patient.
The search party found me in the woods, but I never left my house.
I tried to scream for help, but my voice came out of the television in the other room instead.
The medication stopped working. The doctors I've been seeing were never real. The prescriptions were empty.
My daughter drew a picture of our family. There are seven people in it. We are a family of four.
I looked in the mirror and didn't recognize myself.
A stranger looked back.
But we moved in perfect synchronization.
The man in the corner of my room doesn't move, doesn't breathe, doesn't blink. But every morning he's a little closer.
I've been receiving letters from myself, postmarked from dates in the future. They all say the same thing: Don't trust her.
The support group meets every Tuesday. None of us remember joining. None of us can find the building during the day.
I asked my daughter who she was talking to in her room. She said it was me. I've been at work all day.
The thing that lives in the static between channels has started learning words. Last night it said my social security number.
I understand what the voice is trying to tell me.
It's not the future.
It's a warning from the past.
They say if you type fast enough, it can't catch you. They were wrong. It's already here, reading over your shoulder.
I felt something brush my shoulder as I typed this. The room is empty. I checked twice. Then I heard it laugh.
The building I work in has 14 floors. The elevator sometimes stops at 15. The people who get off never come back.
I've been documenting the thing in my house for months. Last night, I found its journal. It's been documenting me longer.
My therapist told me the trauma isn't real. Then I found her obituary. She died twenty years before I was born.
I see it every time I close my eyes.
It's learning to smile.
Soon it will wear my skin perfectly.
The emergency broadcast has been playing for six hours. It's just my name, repeated, in a voice I almost recognize as my own.
I installed cameras to catch the intruder. The footage shows me sleepwalking, but I'm doing things I don't remember learning how to do.
The thing in the basement stopped knocking. Now it just whispers let me up in perfect imitation of my dead brother's voice.
I've been typing this message for help for three hours. Every time I finish, I find myself back at the beginning with no memory of stopping.
The missing persons report has my photo, my description, my last known location. It was filed by someone with my exact name, six months ago.
My window has scratches on the inside glass.
Deep gouges like fingernails.
From something trying to get out.
I thought I was the only one who could see it. Then I noticed everyone else was just pretending not to. They all looked so afraid.
The voice on the other end of the call was mine, begging me not to answer if it called again. It's been calling every hour since.
I found a box of photographs in my attic. They're all of me, sleeping, taken from inside my bedroom. The timestamps span thirty years. I'm twenty-five.
The creature that replaced my wife makes breakfast every morning and kisses me goodbye. Sometimes I catch it practicing her smile in the mirror. It's getting better.
I stopped being afraid of the dark when I realized the thing hunting me can see perfectly fine in the light. It just prefers to wait until I can't see it coming.
